subsc: Agro-industry, marketing, and trade,Agro-industry,Micro- and SME finance

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Farmer and
            Enterprise Support Project (PFESP) for Romania were as
            follows: outcomes were highly satisfactory, project
            sustainability was likely, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the generally
            successful project outcome underlines a number of positive
            experiences on which to draw in future and lessons learned
            when financing development in former command economies. The
            project also supports the view that credit lines should not
            be strictly directed to specific sub sectors or to export.
            Market demand as indicated through PFESP is the right
            determinant of investment opportunities. The success of the
            projects financed and the pay back performance of
            sub-borrowers, who are successfully amortizing their loans,
            sometimes over shorter periods than initially provided for
            by banks, are clear indications that a sector wide demand
            driven credit project can work. Another important lesson
            learned during the implementation of PFESP is that the
            choice of the apex institution can greatly affect the
            outcome of the project. Appointing the Treasury within
            Ministry of Finance (MOF) as the apex institution for PFESP
            proved disadvantageous as it introduced a public sector
            spending control culture into what should have been a purely
            commercial operation and as a result it generated
            considerable delays in sub loan processing and disbursement.
            These added to the costs and risks of project sub-borrowers
            and considerably frustrated the financial intermediaries
            (FIs') management.
